Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 5 semesters
Starting Months: May
Domestic Tuition: $8,293.00 * † ‡
International Tuition: $20,834.00 ** † ‡
Location: St. James Campus
Experiential Learning: Hybrid in Semester 5 and 7, Online in Semester 6 and 8

Related Programs: Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) (H315), Culinary Management (H100), Culinary Management (Integrated Learning) (H116)

Context:
The H316 bridge pathway is designed for graduates of Culinary Management diploma programs to enter the third year of the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) degree at George Brown College. This degree program combines commerce, culinary, food studies, and externship experiences, preparing graduates for kitchen, operations management, or food development positions.

Key areas of study in the Culinary Management degree include:
- Culinary proficiency
- Culinary theory
- Accounting and finance
- Marketing and communications
- Human resources and risk management
- Specialized business
- Research
- General knowledge (liberal studies)

Students have the opportunity to participate in externships, where they can gain valuable work experience and add it to their resume. Career options for graduates include positions in multi-unit food service such as director of operations with culinary experience requirements or corporate/menu development chef. Other possible career paths are in retirement facilities and chains, such as director of food service, executive chef, or director of food and nutrition.

Context:
The text provides information about various job positions in the Food Service industry and related fields such as Contract Food Service Management, Food Processors and Brokers, Business Consulting, Entrepreneurship, and Educational Pathways.

Positions mentioned include director of food service, executive chef, director of food and beverage, corporate or regional chef, district manager, regional manager, regional vice-president, development chef, sales representative, sales manager, and corporate chef, among others.

The text also mentions courses required for a degree in the Food Service program, including Gastronomy, Principles of Marketing, Fundamentals of Accounting, Research Fundamentals, Managerial Accounting, Macroeconomics: Canada in the Global Environment, Market and Feasibility Research I, Strategic Managerial Communications, Sustainability in Food Service, Finance, Food Science and Nutrition, Human Resources Management, Statistics, and Work Integrated Learning II (WIL).

Graduates of this program may be eligible for direct entry into master's programs in business, gastronomy, and environmental studies. They may also be prepared to own a restaurant or catering services. The text does not provide any factual information such as years, numbers, emails, or names.

Context: The text provides information about the course codes and names offered in Term 7 and Semester 8 of a graduate program at the college. Some of the courses include HOSF 4703 - Restaurant Risk Management, HOSF 4705 - Beverages, Sensory and Evaluation, and HOSF 4804 - Research and Development, among others. The program learning outcomes indicate that graduates will be able to apply current practices in various areas related to culinary management, research and analyze societal and market demands, collaborate effectively, plan and execute cooking techniques, use management theories, develop new food products or events, support large-scale culinary operations, monitor changing practices, and communicate information using advanced verbal and written skills. The tuition for domestic students is $8,293 and for international students is $20,834.

Context: International Tuition for Fall 2022 is $20,834.00. Additional costs include uniform ($290), knives and small wares ($500–$700), books ($1600), black safety shoes ($110–$160), and co-op work term fee (approximately $500). Financial assistance is available through OSAP for eligible applicants. The program requires a Culinary Management diploma with a GPA of 2.7 or higher, completion of Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR, Smart Serve Certificate, Sanitation Certificate, and WHMIS Certificate. Prospective students outside of Ontario require department assessment which may result in additional courses and certificates. The H316 bridge semester takes place at an unspecified date. Contact Warren Ford (wford@georgebrown.ca) for more information. International Students are advised to visit the "International Fees and Related Costs" page for additional details.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) Program (Bridging) H316 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The H316 bridge courses take place from May to August. To continue to semester 5 (Year 3) of the H315 program, students must complete the designated bridge pathway and maintain a minimum 2.3 program GPA (67 per cent or above).

The bridge for entry into semester 5 of the H315 program comprises six core courses: Gastronomy, Principles of Marketing, Fundamentals of Accounting, Research Fundamentals, Managerial Accounting, and Macroeconomics: Canada in the Global Environment.

Current George Brown domestic students in H100 – Culinary Management, H116 – Culinary Management (Integrated Learning), or H119 – Culinary Management – Nutrition programs who wish to apply for H316 should apply on ontariocolleges.ca. Current international students in the same diploma programs who wish to apply for H316 should apply on the Online Application System for International Students.

The George Brown College ESL Level 9, TOEFL 84 overall and 21 in each skill band (online), IELTS 6.5 overall and 6.0 in each skill band, MELAB 85, or CAEL overall 70 (writing 60) are the English language proficiency requirements for the program.

George Brown College has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer this applied degree for a seven-year term starting October 11, 2016.

Context:
Michael Saunders graduated from George Brown College with an Honours Bachelor's Degree in a culinary background program. The degree focused on leadership, communication, food literacy, food science, sustainability of food, Business, Marketing, and risks of operating a business in a hospitality environment. Despite the impact of the global pandemic on his last two years, he was able to complete his education with an Honours degree. Michael emphasizes the importance of understanding the power and knowledge of cooking in creating extraordinary culinary experiences. He encourages the future cohorts to strive for sustainability and make everyone's livelihood nourished and sheltered.

George Brown College offers a Bachelor's Degree program with a focus on a culinary background, including topics such as leadership, communication, food literacy, food science, sustainability, Business, Marketing, and risks of operating a business in a hospitality environment.
